title.narrative: Flood emergency response in Igalamela and Ibaji LGAs of Kogi State

description.narrative: The project is implemented in a consortium with ActionAid, CARE and CAFOD. CAFOD is focusing in Kogi state while the other two agencies will implement in other affected states. High rainfall, climate oscillation, poor dam management, poor preparedness culture as well as weak disaster management architecture among others are responsible for predictable flood disaster in Nigeria. The torrential rainfall between August and September 2019 caused displacement, death, destruction and disruption of livelihoods in Borno, Delta, Kogi, Adamawa, Kebbi, Taraba, Benue among other States. In the last few days, the flooding has had disastrous affects in some of these states. Four States; Borno, Kogi, Delta and Adamawa have been worst hit with the potential for more disaster as the rains continue to poor and rivers overflow their banks. In response to the flood disaster in the state, ActionAid Nigeria responded by first sending out a team of four to carry out a rapid assessment on the extent of damages caused by the flood. The floods bring a rising threat of waterborne diseases, such as cholera and acute watery diarrhoea, which are easily spread through contaminated floodwater. In Kogi, Delta and Kebbi states, many communities are currently displaced and living in makeshift camps or in host communities. These families are in distress and require emergency lifesaving assistance.
